channel.title: BBC News - Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Biden rows back on Facebook 'killing people' comment
item.description: The US president says he was referring to a dozen people spreading misinformation on the platform.

item.title: Northern's ticket machines hit by ransomware cyber attack
item.description: Northern rail's new self-service machines were installed at 420 stations two months ago.

item.title: Apple delays return to office as Covid cases rise
item.description: A three-day-a-week return to the office is reportedly postponed until October.

item.title: Covid: Will lockdown change England's new tech habits?
item.description: The pandemic brought about big changes in the way people use tech - the question is will they last?

item.title: Jeff Bezos launches to space aboard New Shepard rocket ship
item.description: The world's richest man and three other passengers return safely just 11 minutes after take-off.

item.title: Council algorithms mass profile millions, campaigners say
item.description: Most of the software is "secret, unevidenced, invasive and likely discriminatory", Big Brother Watch says.

item.title: China says Microsoft hacking accusations fabricated by US and allies
item.description: There are concerns that the attack on the tech giant suggests China's cyber-behaviour is escalating.

item.title: Twitter suspends Marjorie Taylor Greene over 'misleading' Covid posts
item.description: Georgia Republican Marjorie Taylor Greene has been a vocal critic of vaccines and the use of masks.

item.title: Bitcoin mining machines steamrolled by Malaysia police
item.description: Officers had seized more than 1,000 Bitcoin mining units allegedly powered by stolen electricity.

item.title: Pegasus: Spyware sold to governments 'targets activists'
item.description: Israeli tech firm NSO denies media reports that its software has been sold to authoritarian regimes.

item.title: Writing fake online reviews could be made illegal
item.description: A plan to crack down on online rip-offs has been outlined by the government.

item.title: Royal Navy tests drones above and below waves
item.description: A broad exercise saw the navy test scouts, resupply, and underwater reconnaissance drones.

item.title: Spyware: The software that watches you
item.description: BBC’s cyber reporter, Joe Tidy, agreed to be spied on to understand the spyware experience further.

item.title: Custom glasses: Will 3D-printing change our eyewear?
item.description: Eyewear can be more tailored to an individual’s face producing a better fit and reduce overstocking.

item.title: Robot helps people get dressed and other tech news
item.description: Romana Kreider looks at some of the best technology news stories of the week.

item.title: Duran Duran’s Invisible: 'Thrilled' with AI collaboration
item.description: Musician Nick Rhodes explains why artificial intelligence was key in making their new music video.

item.title: How MetaHuman Creator helped me create ‘Dana’
item.description: Realistic digital humans can be produced rapidly with the new software, Epic Games says.

item.title: Finding 'Grace': Murder, DNA and ancestry
item.description: How a novel use of DNA and ancestry websites is helping police uncover clues in cold case murders.

item.title: Why was my tweet about football labelled abusive?
item.description: A BBC journalist sets out to discover how Twitter moderates posts after he was banned from the platform.

item.title: Pegasus: Who are the alleged victims of spyware targeting?
item.description: Jamal Khashoggi's wife and the editor of the Financial Times are among those said to be targeted.

item.title: NHS Covid app: Should it stay or should it go?
item.description: There is a clash over the future of the NHS tracing app, as many delete it - or ignore its alerts.

item.title: Using plastic waste to help solve sand shortages
item.description: With construction sand in short supply crushed plastic is being used as an alternative.

item.title: How your personal data is being scraped from social media
item.description: As hackers scoop up data from social media sites, should firms be taking better care of your data?
